page.title: 04Early History,Crayke Village
page.content:
The name Crayke comes from the Celtic word for rock or crag, and has been spelt in many ways in the past, Creca, Cric, Creic, Crec, Crayk, Crek, Craik and finally Crayke. It was situated on an ancient Celtic trackway to the Tees via Hambelton Hills, traces of the early occupation of the site include the finding of Roman, Saxon and Viking items.
From very early farming has been te mainstay of Crayke. By Saxon times 240 acres were cultivated close around the village, later the outer woodland were cleared to form large ox and horse pastures and between 1680 and 1760 of these were divided into smaller fields and in the same period outlying farmhouses were built.
